original_theorem: Prove that for any $a, b, c$ that are side lengths of a triangle, the following inequality holds: $(a+b-c)(b+c-a)(c+a-b) \leq a b c$.

```lean4
    (hab : a + b > c) (hbc : b + c > a) (hca : c + a > b) :
    (a + b - c) * (b + c - a) * (c + a - b) ≤ a * b * c := by
```

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• a,b,c are positive real numbers [tc_1].
• The factors a+b-c, b+c-a, c+a-b are positive [l4].
• $a^2 \ge (a-b+c)(a+b-c)$ [l5].
• $b^2 \ge (b-a+c)(b+a-c)$ [l6].
• $c^2 \ge (c-a+b)(c+a-b)$ [l7].
Therefore, we conclude:
• $a^2 b^2 c^2 \ge (a-b+c)(a+b-c)(b-a+c)(b+a-c)(c-a+b)(c+a-b)$ [l8].
